titlepage.titleproper: A Guide to the Stanley Legum experimental linguistics collection, DATES
titlepage.subtitle:
A Collection in
Special Collections and Archives C0125
titlepage.author: Eron Ackerman

archdesc.runner: Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University

did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: George Mason University. Special Collections and Archives.

did.unittitle: Stanley Legum experimental linguistics collection
did.abstract: This collection contains research materials on linguistics in the areas of generative-transformational syntax, phonology, reading, psycholinguistics, and sociolinguistics. It includes work by LaBov, Bach Peters, Karttunen, G. Lakoff, R. Lakoff, Chomsky, Ross, Berdan, McCawley, and many others.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: There are no restrictions on personal use. Permission to publish material from the Stanley Legum experimental linguistics collection must be obtained from Special Collections Research Center, George Mason University Libraries.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Stanley Legum experimental linguistics collection, C0125, Special Collections and Archives, George Mason University Libraries.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Collection donated by Stanley Legum in 1982.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Special Collections and Archives staff. EAD markup completed by Eron Ackerman and Jordan Patty in April 2009.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: Stanley Legum studied linguistics and lived in Fairfax, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains research materials on linguistics in the areas of generative-transformational syntax, phonolgy, reading, psycholinguistics, and sociolinguistics. It includes work by LaBov, Bach Peters, Karttunen, G. Lakoff, R. Lakoff, Chomsky, Ross, Berdan, McCawley, and many others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged by subject.
